titleStmt.title: Adaptive Fault Tolerant Control of Cooperative Heterogeneous Systems with Actuator Faults and Unreliable Interconnections

analytic.title: Adaptive Fault Tolerant Control of Cooperative Heterogeneous Systems with Actuator Faults and Unreliable Interconnections

div.p: This paper studies the active fault-tolerant control (FTC) problem for nonidentical high-order multi-agent systems, in the presence of actuator faults and network disconnections. The follower agents are enabled to track the output of a leader agent in faulty cases, by performing output feedback actuator fault compensations and distributed accommodations of network disconnections. In view of nonidentical nonlinearities, a highgain observer like-protocol and a cooperative FTC controller are presented, with a synchronization condition to govern the global behavior in undirected/directed graphs. To distributively achieve the synchronization condition by updating local controller parameters, two broadcast mechanisms are presented on a spanning tree (for undirected graphs) and a cycle containing all nodes (for directed graphs). To ensure the tolerance to disconnections, the proposed broadcast mechanisms are redesigned by adding redundant information flows on spanning trees (for undirected graphs) and cycles containing all nodes (for directed graphs).

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: A Multi-agent system (MAS) is a group of interacting in- telligent agents within a networked environment. Multiagent systems can address the problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent to solve. Due to its potential application in many areas, (e.g., formation of satellites, flocking of mobile vehicles, scheduling of automated highway systems [1]), the control of MAS, namely the cooperative control, has received tremendous attention. The interested readers are referred to the seminal works [2]- [6]. Generally speaking, the cooperative control problem is classified into two types: the cooperative regulation and the cooperative tracking [7]. The former, also referred as (leaderless) consensus, synchronization, or rendezvous [8], is to design distributive controllers driving all collected nodes to an un-prescribed common value (consensus equilibrium) [5]. In contrast, the latter is to use a leader agent (node) guiding other ones, by sending the desired trajectory to a small portion of agents. The latter is also referred as leader-following consensus [9],

Hong-Jun Ma and Guang-Hong Yang are with College of Information Science and Engineering, Northeastern University, and State Key Laboratory of Synthetical Automation for Process Industries (Northeastern University), Shenyang, 110819, P. R. China (e-mail: mahongjun@ise.neu.edu.cn;yangguanghong@ise.neu.edu.cn).
synchronization to a leader [10], model reference consensus [11], leader-following control [12], or pinning control [13].

Due to an increasing number of the equipped actuators, sensors and other system components, the reliability requirement of MAS is rapidly enhanced [14]. Recently, researchers have been investigating various faulty scenarios, to improve the fault-tolerance of decentralized systems [15]- [24]. In general, two kinds of faults in MASs need to be considered: the node faults (changing the individual dynamics) and the interconnections faults (affecting the network topology or communication condition). As an example, consider a power grid consisting of a large number of generators. The synchronization of power generators is crucial to ensure steady power supplies across a wide area. Unfortunately, such complex architecture is fragile to the local generator faults and the disconnections among generators. Both kinds of faults are frequent and have undesirable impacts on the power supply (see [25], [26]). However, the conventional fault-tolerant control methods for centralized systems are only useful to ensure the local node's stability. To prevent cascading instability and eventual collapse, a specific group of generators need to be cut off or connected, according to the prescribed rules [26]. This is to say, when compensating for node faults distributively, it is natural and important to use intentional switchings in cooperative control laws when critical nodes are connected or disconnected. Suppose that a cooperative network has been working steadily for a period, if two kinds of faults occur and thus synchronization is destroyed, one might ask: how to still achieve the cooperative objective by compensating for node faults and adjusting the remaining links?

Motivated by the conventional fault-tolerant control approaches on centralized systems, the existing results of cooperative fault-tolerant control (CFTC) are mainly focused on the node faults. In general, the existing results are classified into two types: the passive CFTC approach and the active one. Passive CFTC approach is concerned with robust control techniques with respect to an a priori fixed set of faults (e.g., [15]- [21]). Whereas, active CFTC approach consists of online reconfiguration to recover the stability and other performances when a diagnostic algorithm detects a fault (e.g., [23] and [24]). However, few CFTC method is available for node faults and interconnection faults by dynamically scheduling the redundancy in both individual nodes and network topology.

This paper studies an active CFTC approach for an MAS such that follower agents track the output of a leader in spite of actuator faults and network disconnections. Two basic problems are investigated: adaptive compensation with neighborhood output information for actuator faults under a fixed topology; distributed accommodation via switching within a preselected set of cooperative controllers when disconnections disable the current controller. These two problems are of particular significance for the following reasons. First, a network of heterogeneous nodes with unknown nonlinearities may not retain its stability in the presence of node faults by output feedback even for a fixed topology. Therefore, seeking for synchronization condition in the presence of unknown nonidenticality and designing CFTC controller for high-order nonlinear systems with output information are not trivial. Second, if synchronization is impossible for the current distributive controller when disconnections occur, synchronization may still be achieved via switching between pre-designed CFTC controllers according to neighborhood signals. This certainly increases the applicable possibility of synchronization.

Respect to the vast existing literature on cooperative control, our result has three distinct features. First of all, a faulty networked system is regarded as a time-varying switched uncertain system with input bias for the convenience of addressing the CFTC problem. In particular, output synchronization is achieved by suitably designing neighborhood signals to coordinate the CFTC controllers. To the best of our knowledge, no results have appeared using broadcast mechanisms of finding accessible links to enhance the tolerance against disconnections. The second one is that unlike state feedback CFTC control approaches (e.g., [17]- [22] and [24]), a distributed estimation-based CFTC controller design provides an important approach in the study where only neighborhood information is not sufficient [27]- [30]. The third one is that the considered high-order MAS has nonlinearities both in state and input without additional limitations such as first-or secondorder [31], linearity condition [32]- [37], input nonlinearity [38], [39] and strict-feedback form [40]- [44].

Different from the classical methods dealing with nonlinearities in MAS [38]- [44], in order to achieve the output feedback CFTC objective, a series of techniques are newly developed in this work: 1) A new framework of high-gain observerlike protocol and cooperative controller is proposed to design an output feedback controller, by decoupling the topology structure from Lyapunov equations (see Lemmas 3,6 & 7); 2) To compensate for the actuator faults, a distributive projection algorithm with relative output information is presented (see Theorem 1); 3) In the presence of state-dependent nonlinearities, a non-separation principle-based Lyapunov analysis is proposed without going through the recursive design procedure as done in the backstepping method for the strict-feedback form (see Theorem 1); 4) To coordinate the behaviors of all agents in faulty situation, the information flow is planned by two broadcast mechanisms to cope with disconnections (see Theorems 2 & 3); 5) To fulfill the task of output tracking in the presence of disconnections, a logic-based switching control approach is proposed in a distributive way (see Theorems 4 & 5).

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, basic notations are given. Then in Section III, the problem formulation of CFTC control with actuator faults and lossy interconnections is given. In Sections IV and V, the main technical results of this paper are given, including the broadcastbased CFTC control mothed. An illustrative numerical simulation is presented in Section VI. Finally, Section VII draws the conclusion.

Notations: Let R m×n denote the set of m × n real matrices. Let N denote the set of natural numbers. I n ∈ R n×n is the identity matrix. Π i is the i-th row vector of the identity matrix. diag(A i ) is a block-diagonal matrix with matrices A i . A matrix is Hurwitz (or stable) if all of its eigenvalues have strictly negative real part. Matrix P > 0(P ≥ 0) means P is positive definite (positive semidefinite). λ max (A) and λ min (A) are the maximum eigenvalue and the minimum eigenvalue of symmetric matrix A respectively. A⊗B denotes the Kronecker product of matrices A and B. 0 n ∈ R n , 1 n ∈ R n are the vectors with all entries being zero and one respectively.
div.formula: sup x∈Ω f (x) is the supremum of a continuous function f (x) on a compact set Ω. For three integers a, b and c, a ≡ b (mod c) means that c divides a -b. N = {1, 2, • • • , N },
div.p: where N is a natural number.

div.head: A. Graph Theory
div.formula: A directed graph (digraph) G is a pair (V, E), where V = {v 1 , • • • , v N }is
div.p: a nonempty finite set of nodes and E ⊆ V × V is a set of edges, in which an edge is represented by an ordered pair of distinct nodes. For an edge (v i , v j ), node v i is called the earlier node, node v j the latter node, and v i is a neighbor of v j , denoted by
div.formula: v i ∈ N j = {i|(v i , v j ) ∈ E}. A graph with the property that (v i , v j ) ∈ E implies (v j , v i ) ∈ E for any v i , v j ∈ V, is said to be undirected. A path of length l -1 from node v i1 to node v il is a sequence of ordered edges of the form (v i k , v i k+1 ), k = 1, • • • , l -1. A subgraph G s = (V s , E s ) of G is a graph such that V s ⊆ V and E s ⊆ E.
div.p: A tree is an undirected graph in which any two nods are connected by exactly one path. An undirected graph is connected if there exists a path between every pair of distinct nodes. A spanning tree T of a connected, undirected graph G is a tree composed of all nodes in G. An undirected graph is connected if and only if it contains a spanning tree. A tree is called a rooted tree if one node has been designated the root node, in which the edges have a natural orientation, towards or away from the root. In a rooted tree, the parent of a node is the unique node connected to it on the path to the root node; a child of a node v is a node of which v is the parent; a leaf node is a node that has no child node. A digraph is strongly connected if there is a path from v i to v j for all distinct nodes v i , v j ∈ V. A cycle in a digraph is a sequence of nodes starting and ending at the same node. A digraph is strongly connected if and only if it contains a cycle containing all nodes. The adjacency matrix
div.formula: (a ij ) ∈ R N ×N associated with G is defined by a ij = 1 if (v i , v i ) ∈ E and a ij = 0 otherwise. The Laplacian matrix L = (L ij ) ∈ R N ×N is defined as L ii = j =i a ij and L ij = -a ij , i = j. The degree matrix D is defined by D = diag(d i ) ∈ R N ×N with d i = i∈N a ij
div.p: and the Laplacian matrix as L = D -A. For undirected graphs, both A and L are symmetric.

div.head: III. BACKGROUND AND PROBLEM STATEMENT
div.p: The considered CFTC problem is to enable follower agents to track the output of a leader in the presence of actuator faults and disconnections, which is formulated mathematically at the end of this section.

div.head: A. Node Dynamics
div.p: 1. Follower Node: Consider a group of N (N > 2, N ∈ N) nodes, distributed on a communication graph G, the i-th follower node (1 ≤ i ≤ N ) has the following dynamics
div.formula: ẋi,1 = x i,2 + φ i,1 (x i ), . . . ẋi,n-1 = x i,n + φ i,n-1 (x i ), ẋi,n = u i + φ i,n (x i ), y i = x i,1(1)
div.p: where
div.formula: x i = [x i,1 , • • • , x i,n ] T ∈ R n is the state; u i ∈ R is the control input; y i ∈ R is the output; the functions φ i,j : R n → R (i = 1, • • • , N, j = 1, • • • , n
div.p: ) are assumed to be unknown and locally Lipschitz in R with φ i,j (0 n ) = 0.

div.head: Leader Node:
div.p: As an exosystem that generates a desired trajectory, the leader node, labeled 0, has the following dynamics
where
div.formula: x 0 = [x 0,1 , • • • , x 0,n ] T ∈ R n is the state; y 0 ∈ R is the output; the functions φ 0,j : [0, ∞) × R n → R (j = 1, • • • , n)
div.p: are locally Lipschitz in x 0 with φ 0,j (t, 0 n ) = 0, and they are unknown to all other nodes. As [7], φ 0,j are piecewise continuous in t, which means that the leader node has a timevarying dynamics. To avoid finite time escape phenomenon, system (2) is assumed to be forward complete, that is, for every initial condition, the solution x 0 exists for all t ≥ t 0 .
3. Node Nonlinearities: The unknown nonliearities φ i,j
div.formula: (i = 0, • • • , N, j = 1, • • • , n) have the following universal approximation form on a prescribed compact set Ω ⊂ R n φ i,j (x i ) = w i,j T h(x i ) + µ i,j(3)
div.p: where h(x i ) ∈ R m is a suitable set of m basis functions, w i,j ∈ R m is the ideal weight vector and µ i,j is the approximation error. In the presented CFTC controller of node i, the following approximation of φ i,j (x i ) is applied φi,j (x i ) = ŵT i,j h(x i ) where ŵi ∈ R m is the estimation value of the ideal weights provided by off-line or on-line experimental designs. In general, the approximation error satisfies φ i,j (x i ) -φi,j (x i ) = wT i,j h(x i ) + µ i,j where wi,j = w i,j -ŵi,j , µ i,j is bounded but not needed to be known. Such approximation can be performed, according to the results on neural networks (NNs) and fuzzy logic systems (FLSs) [45]- [48], etc., in which h(x i ) is chosen as sigmoids, Gaussians or fuzzy knowledge basis, w i,j is the ideal weight vector of NNs or FLSs with the approximation error µ i,j .

Remark 1. As the seminal works [45]- [49], the approximation (3) can be constructed by neural networks (NNs) or fuzzy logic systems (FLSs). There are also many successful applications of NNs or FLSs in the cooperative control of high-order multi-agent systems [23], [41]- [42]. All these results provide good references on how to get the suitable approximation for unknown nonlinear functions.

div.head: B. Network Topology and Neighborhood Communication
div.p: 1. Network Topology: The collected nodes (1) and ( 2) are distributed on a graph G. As [7], the leader node can be observed from a small subset of nodes in graph G. If Node i observes the leader, and edge (v 0 , v i ) is said to exist with weighting gain g i > 0. The pinning matrix is defined as G = diag(g i ) ∈ R N ×N . For undirected and directed cases, the following assumptions are imposed.
Assumption 1. The undirected graph G with disconnections contains a spanning tree T , in which the root node i r can observe information from the leader node, i.e., g ir > 0.
Assumption 2. The digraph G with disconnections is strongly connected, and at least one node, namely i c , can observe information from the leader node, i.e., g ic > 0.
According to [50], for a digraph G, Assumption 2 is equivalent to Assumption 3 below.

div.head: Assumption 3. The digraph G with disconnections contains a cycle C containing all nodes and at least one node, namely
div.p: Node i c , can observe information from the leader node, i.e., g ic > 0.

div.head: Neighborhood Communication:
div.p: For Node i (i ∈ N ), xi ∈ R n is the estimate of the state x i , and define ŷi = C xi as the estimation of the output y i . Define ỹi = y i -ŷi as the output estimation error. The following relative output feedback signals are transmitted among nodes. Definition 1. [7] The neighborhood state estimation error i is defined as
div.formula: i = j∈Ni a ij (x j -xi ) + g i (x 0 -xi ).
div.p: Definition 2. [7] The neighborhood output estimation ζ i is defined as
div.formula: ζ i = j∈Ni a ij (ỹ j -ỹi ) + g i (ỹ 0 -ỹi ).
div.p: Consider leader node 0 acts as a command generator, assume that x0 = x 0 and ỹ0 = 0. The signals xi , ỹi are directly available to Node i, and xi , ỹi are transmitted from Node j or the leader if a ij = 0 or g i = 0. a i,j and g i are given in G a priori knowledge based on which the controller design is proposed. Assumption 4. The communication time delay between v i , v j on edge (v i , v j ) is less than T , T > 0.

By interacting the nodes in neighborhood N i with the exchanged signals i , ζ i , this work presents the following observer-based distributed controller u * i for Node i, to achieve a desired cooperative behavior.

( 4)-( 5), the neighborhood state estimation error i is introduced to design the distributive controller, in contrast, the neighborhood output estimation ζ i is necessary to construct the observer-like protocol.

div.head: C. Node Actuator Fault Scenario
div.p: For Node i, the faulty actuator signal u F i is defined as
div.formula: u F i = u i + ψ i , t ≥ t F i (6)
div.p: where ψ i is a constant representing the bias in the actuator, and the faulty time instant t F i is unknown.
Assumption 5. The unknown constant ψ i satisfies ψ i ≤ ψ i ≤ ψi , with ψ i , ψi being known constants.

Remark 2. In the literature, there are standard techniques to handle the bias faults (e.g., [54] and [55]) for centralized systems. But for the networked nonidentical high-order nonlinear systems ( 1) and ( 2), there are no available CFTC control approaches by relative output measurement information.

div.head: D. Cooperative Fault Tolerant Control Problem
div.p: Define the global state as
div.formula: x = [x T 1 , • • • , x T N ] T ; the tracking error as δ i = x i -x 0 ; the global tracking error as δ = x - x 0 , x 0 = 1 N ⊗ x 0 ; the global output tracking error as δ o = [δ o1 , • • • , δ oN ] T , δ oi = Cδ i .

div.head: Definition 3. [7] (Cooperative Uniform Ultimate Boundedness) For N Nodes, the global output tracking error δ o is said to be cooperative uniformly ultimately bounded (CUUB)
div.p: if there exists a compact set Ω δ ⊂ R N n with the property that {0 N n } ⊂ Ω δ , so that for all δ(t 0 ) ∈ Ω δ , there exist a bound B δ and a finite time
div.formula: T δ such that δ o ≤ B δ , for all t ≤ t 0 + T δ .

div.head: The objective of the considered cooperative fault tolerant control problem is to
div.p: • Design a nominal controller u * i for the system with no fault and nonlinearity, such that lim t→∞ δ o = 0 N , • Design an FTC controller u C i = u * i -ψi with ψi being the estimation for ψ i , in the presence of actuator faults and lossy connections, such that δ o is CUUB with a bound B δ .

div.head: IV. CONSENSUS PROTOCOL AND COOPERATIVE CONTROLLER
div.p: This section presents a high-gain observer-like protocol and a cooperative controller with tunable parameters θ i to stabilize the nominal system. Then a distributed projection algorithm is given to compensate for the actuator faults.

div.head: A. Framework of High-Gain Observer-Like Protocol and Cooperative Controller
div.p: In this subsection, a framework of high-gain observer-like protocol and cooperative controller is developed for the normal system. F (the consensus protocol gain) in Eq. ( 4) is designed as
div.formula: F (θ i ) = [l 1 /θ i , • • • , l n /θ i n ] T and K (the cooperative controller gain) in Eq. (5) as K(θ i ) = [k 1 /θ i n , • • • , k n /θ i ], where l 1 , • • • , l n , k 1 , • • • , k n are constants; θ i is a tunable local control gain parameter. div.p: Remark 3. The reason of introducing gain parameters θ i in the protocol and controller is to handle the nonlinearities and node faults in MAS. This idea has been applied in centralized FTC systems [56]. The cooperative control of the closed-loop system ( 8) and ( 7) should consider two kinds of unknown nonlinearities: Φ(x) -Φ(x) in distributive estimators and Φ(x) -Φ(x 0 ) in cooperative controllers.

The nonlinearities of Φ(x) -Φ(x) and Φ(x) -Φ(x 0 ) are analyzed in the following lemma, which shows that these nonidentities are bounded by some linear-growth functions of the tracking error x i -x 0 and the estimation error x i -xi with unknown rates and error bounds respectively.

div.head: C. Fault Compensation Mechanism Based on Distributed Projection Algorithm
div.p: To compensate for the effect of the actuator fault (6), the nominal controller u * i is redesigned as
div.formula: u C i = u * i -ψi . (17

div.p: Remark 6. Compared with the reports of passive CFTC control such as [15]- [21], this paper proposes an active CFTC control approach to relax the conservatism of these passive methods; compared with the CFTC control approaches such as [23], [24], the compensation here does not need a fault diagnosis mechanism, and the CFTC controller is design by relative output feedback.

div.head: D. Compact Form of Closed-loop System with Actuator Faults
div.p: In the presence of the actuator faults (6), by applying compensation mechanism (17), the actual control actuation for Node i is

div.p: Remark 7. In the overall closed-loop system ( 19)-( 20), the local controller gain θ i is introduced to accommodate the protocol and the cooperative controller to handle the nonlinearities and node actuator faults. θ i (i ∈ N ) has to be updated online according to local and neighborhood information.

div.head: V. BROADCAST-BASED CFTC CONTROLLER DESIGN FOR MULTI-AGENT SYSTEMS
div.p: For connected undirected graphs and strongly connected digraphs, this section first derives a CUUB synchronization condition for a fixed topology. The CUUB synchronization condition ensures an exponential convergence on a prescribed time interval, which needs the global information. To achieve distributively the synchronization condition, at every scheduled switching time, all nodes determine whether to update its controller or not. The update rules depend only on the local and neighborhood signals, which are broadcasted on the spanning tree or the cycle containing all nodes. Furthermore, the tolerance to disconnections is considered to redesign the proposed broadcast-based update rules.

div.head: B. Broadcast-Based Strategy for Fixed Undirect Graphs
div.p: In practical network environments, the global information is difficult or impossible to acquire. To achieve the synchronization condition proposed before, the local controller gains θ i have to be updated based on the local and neighborhood information. To this end, the following signals (see sub-figure (a) in Fig. 1) are broadcasted on a spanning tree, to coordinate the updates for the local controllers.

div.head: Theorem 2. Under Assumptions 1,4 and 5, suppose that the adaptive CFTC controller developed in Section IV with Tuning Mechanism 1 is applied to the cooperative systems (1)-(2).
div.p: For any initial conditions satisfying x 0 (t 0 ) ∈ Ω, x i (t 0 ) ∈ Ω and V (δ(t 0 ), x(t 0 ), ψ(t 0 )) ≤ υ, all closed-loop states are bounded on [t 0 , ∞) and moreover, the bounded output tracking is achieved.

Proof: According to the switching mechanism, at any time t p , each node updates its local controller gain θ i according to the pre-selected sequence Θ, until Node i (i ∈ N ) satisfies the condition πi = π i = 1. For any fixed θ i (i ∈ N ), the closedloop solution exists till the next switching time. So the overall solution can be defined as the concatenations of solutions between successive switchings. The solution of the closed-loop (switching) system exists. Thus define its maximum interval of existence as [t 0 , t f ).

It is first shown that if all θ i are switched only a finite number of times, then t f = ∞ and the bounded output tracking problem is solved. Let t p * be the time at which the final (p * th) switching occurs. According to Switching Logic 1, the following fact is established (otherwise a further switching would occur): for all t > t p * , |ỹ i | ≤ σ i and ξ i ≤ σ i . This implies that δ oi are bounded for all t > t p * . Thus, the global output track error δ o is cooperative uniformly ultimately bounded (CUUB) on [0, t f ) and hence t f = ∞.

Next it is shown that indeed all θ i can be switched only a finite number of times. Seeking a contradiction, suppose on the contrary that θ i can be switched an infinite number of times. Consider all gains θ i are fixed on every interval [t p , t p + LT ], a similar derivation as Theorem 1 yields
div.formula: V (δ, x, ψ) ≤ -λ min (Π) • ( E θ δ 2 + E θ x 2 + ψ 2 ) + √ 2Ξ E θ δ 2 + E θ x 2 + ψ 2 + α 5 θ.

div.p: So no further switching can occur-a contradiction yields. Therefore, all θ i can be switched only a finite number of times. Thus for any initial conditions, all closed-loop states are bounded on [t 0 , ∞) and moreover, the bounded output tracking is proved.

Theorem 3. Under Assumptions 2-5, suppose that the adaptive CFTC controller developed in Section IV with Turning Mechanism 2 is applied to the cooperative systems ( 1)-( 2). Then for any initial conditions satisfying x 0 (t 0 ) ∈ Ω, x i (t 0 ) ∈ Ω and V (δ(t 0 ), x(t 0 ), ψ(t 0 )) ≤ υ, all closed-loop states are bounded on [t 0 , ∞) and moreover, the bounded output tracking is achieved.

Proof: Following a similar deriviation of Theorem 2, the key is to show the following facts: 1) The overall solution is well defined on a maximum interval of existence as [t 0 , t f ), considering that each node updates its local controller gain θ i until π i = 1. 2) If all θ i are switched only a finite number of times, then t f = ∞ with satisfied output tracking errors. 3) The selections of K, L, c and ∆ imply that all θ i are switched only a finite number of times.

div.head: D. Improved Tolerance to Network Disconnections
div.p: Now, the topology is assumed to be time-varying under the changeable communication connections. To achieve the CFTC objective, a certain amount of connectivity redundancy has to be added. It is assumed that the link between the leader node (Node 0) and Node i r in undirected graphs, or the link between the leader node and Node i c in digraphs, is always connected. Without loss of generality, suppose that in undirected graphs, there are s (s > 1) spanning trees T 0 , • • • , T s-1 , with the same root node (Node i r ). In the presence of disconnections, G contains at least one spanning tree; in digraphs, there are
div.formula: k (k > 1) cycles containing all nodes C 0 , • • • , C k-1 .
div.p: In the presence of disconnections, G contains at least one cycle containing all nodes. Such requirements are imposed by adding 'backups' of spanning trees in undirected graphs or adding 'backups' of cycles containing all nodes in directed graphs.

The leader node is controlled by a linear proportionalderivative (PD) algorithm u pd = K p (y -y -d) + K d ( ẏ -ẏd ), where K p = 5000rad and K d = 500rad • s. y d is chosen to be y d = 30cos(t). The initial conditions are: x 0 (0) = [5.2, 0, 95.36, 0, 0] T , x 1 (0) = [10, 0, 50, 0, 0] T , x 2 (0) = [15.2, 5, 95.36, 0, 0] T , x 3 (0) = [25.2, 0, 55.36, 2, 0] T , x 4 (0) = [0, 0, 45, 0, 0] T . x1 (0) = x2 (0) = x3 (0) = x4 (0) = [0, 0, 0, 0, 0] T . ψ1 (0) = ψ2 (0) = ψ3 (0) = ψ4 (0). All output tracking error bounds are selected as 0.1m. The turning mechanism is set with T = 5s and the communication time delay is chosen as 0.01s.

div.head: Case 1: Undirected Graph with Disconnections
div.p: The undirected graph for simulation is shown in sub-figure (a) of Fig. 2, the weights a i,j of the edges are selected to be 1 if Node i and Node j are connected. At t = 10s, the edge (1, 4) is disconnected, i.e., a 1,4 = a 4,1 = 0, for t > 10s. The broadcast signals π i and πi are designed for all spanning trees as Tuning Mechanism 1'. Thus Assumption 1 is satisfied.

Sub-figure (a) in Fig. 3 shows that the response curves of the output measurement of Node i, i = 1, 2, 3, 4 with comparisons to the one of the leader node (Node 0). It is clear that in sub-figure (b) of Fig. 3 that all the output tracking errors are kept bounded as prescribed by bound 0.1m after 30s. In sub-figure (a) in Fig. 4, the control inputs of all nodes are plotted, which shows that after three switchings in i all nodes are coordinated by the broadcast-based strategy 1'. During the local controller gain accommodations, the fault compensations for ψ 1 and ψ 3 are well performed, which are shown in the estimations of ψ i , i = 1, 2, 3, 4 in sub-figure (b) in Fig. 4. These figures demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed CFTC control strategy for an undirected network with disconnections.

div.head: Case 2: Digraph with Disconnections
div.p: In sub-figure (b) in Fig. 2, the directed graph for simulation is shown, in which the weights i,j of the edges are selected to be 1 if Node i and Node j are connected. For simulation of network disconnections, the edge (4, 2) is omitted for t > 5. The broadcast signals π i are designed for all cycles containing all nodes as Tuning Mechanism 2'. It can be seen that Assumptions 2, 3 are satisfied. For comparison, sub-figure (a) in Fig. 5 shows that the response curves of the output measurement of Node i, i = 1, 2, 3, 4 and the one of the leader node (Node 0). All the output tracking errors are kept bounded as prescribed by bound 0.1m after 30s, which is shown in sub-figure (b) of Fig. 5. In sub-figure (a) in Fig. 3, after four switchings in θ i in local controller gains, the distributed controller inputs of all nodes are plotted and all nodes are coordinated by the broadcastbased strategy 2'. At the same time, the faults of ψ 1 and ψ 3 are estimated and compensated, which are shown in the estimations of ψ i , i = 1, 2, 3, 4 in sub-figure (b) in Fig. 6. Compounded with the Figures 3456, all these figures validate the applicability of the proposed CFTC control strategy for an undirected/directed network, even in the presence of communication disconnections.

Essentially, the quick reaction and the low tracking errors in the faulty situations are what this work pursues. As a trade off, such consideration results in poorer transient performance, which is partly caused by the delay in fault estimation and compensation, the switchings in the controller parameters. Although such performance degradation is inevitable, from the response curves in Fig. 3-Fig. 6, the proposed CFTC control method has an acceptable degradation. In general, the simulation results for both cases of undirected graphs and digraphs can demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed FTC scheme.

div.head: VII. CONCLUSION
div.p: In this paper, a CFTC control approach is proposed for a group of high-order nonidentical nonlinear systems in the presence of actuator faults and disconnections. The compensation for the actuator faults is implemented by indirect adaptive control techniques with only relative output information. For connected undirected graphs and strongly connected digraphs, a framework of high-gain observer-like protocol and cooperative controller is presented with broadcast mechanisms to achieve distributively a synchronization condition dependent on global information. By adding redundant broadcast signals on the spanning trees and the cycles containing all nodes, the proposed CFTC control strategy is improved with a tolerance to lossy interconnections. Finally, a numerical example is used to illustrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

In our future work, the proposed broadcast mechanism design is to be investigated on the related topics, such as the optimal choice of leader node with minimized convergence error, the removement of the faulty node with diagnosis, the event-based broadcast mechanism design with less information flows. The researches on these distributed approaches must take into account the computation, bandwidth, and energy constraints in the decentralized environments, as well as the limited, local information available to individual agent.

The changes of network topology damaging the current spanning tree or the cycle containing all nodes resultsin the switchings in each local controller gain θ i . Postdoctoral Fellow. From 2001 to 2005, he was a Research Scientist/Senior Research Scientist with the National University of Singapore. He is currently a Professor at the College of Information Science and Engineering, Northeastern University. His current research interests include fault-tolerant control, fault detection and isolation, non-fragile control systems design, and robust control. Dr. Yang is an Associate Editor for the International Journal of Control, Automation, and Systems (IJCAS), the International Journal of Systems Science (IJSS), the IET Control Theory & Applications, and the IEEE Transactions on Fuzzy Systems.
